us_person_worldwide_filing.name: U.S. person (citizen/green-card holder) - worldwide U.S. filing
us_person_worldwide_filing.description: You are a U.S. citizen or U.S. lawful permanent resident (green-card holder). The U.S. taxes you on worldwide income each year, regardless of where you live. You generally use the foreign tax credit to relieve double taxation; foreign asset/account reporting may also apply.

us.note: Annual U.S. individual income tax return reporting worldwide income
Claim credit for income tax paid to Canada to mitigate double tax
Report specified foreign financial assets if thresholds are met
Report non-U.S. financial accounts if aggregate balance exceeds USD $10,000 at any time

us_person_worldwide_filing.why: U.S. persons must report worldwide income on Form 1040; Form 1116 prevents double taxation. Form 8938 and FBAR satisfy foreign asset/account disclosure when thresholds are met.

canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.name: Canadian tax resident (worldwide Canadian filing)
canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.description: You are a resident of Canada for tax purposes (factual or deemed). Canada taxes residents on worldwide income; foreign tax credits may be claimed for U.S. taxes paid. Foreign asset reporting may also apply.

ca.note: Annual Canadian individual income tax return reporting worldwide income
Claim federal foreign tax credit for U.S. income taxes paid
Report specified foreign property if cost amount exceeded CAD $100,000 at any time

canadian_tax_resident_worldwide_filing.why: Canadian residents report worldwide income on the T1; Schedule T2209 provides federal foreign tax credit relief for U.S.-taxed income. T1135 fulfills foreign asset disclosure when thresholds are met.

us_resident_substantial_presence.name: U.S. resident by substantial presence test
us_resident_substantial_presence.description: You spent enough days physically in the U.S. this year (weighted 3-year formula) to be treated as a U.S. tax resident. You file a full U.S. resident return unless you qualify for an exception (e.g., closer connection).

us.note: if you're nonresident under that exception

us_resident_substantial_presence.why: Establishes your U.S. tax status; 8840 is required to claim the closer-connection exception to SPT.

snowbird_closer_connection.name: Snowbird with closer connection to Canada (Form 8840)
snowbird_closer_connection.description: You were in the U.S. enough days to otherwise meet SPT but keep stronger ties to Canada and qualify to be taxed as a U.S. nonresident.

us.note: stand-alone if no 1040-NR is required, or attached to 1040-NR if you must file

snowbird_closer_connection.why: Discloses the treaty/closer-connection facts so the IRS accepts nonresident status.

residency_change_dual_status.name: Residency change / dual-status year
residency_change_dual_status.description: You became/ceased to be a U.S. resident mid-year (or vice-versa for Canada).
residency_change_dual_status.why: Each country taxes you on different bases before/after the switch; filings split the year correctly. (General treaty framework in the Canada-U.S. Convention.)

treaty_based_position.name: Treaty-based position disclosure
treaty_based_position.description: You are taking a position under the Canada-U.S. treaty that overrides the default U.S. tax rules.
treaty_based_position.why: U.S. law requires disclosure when a treaty position reduces or modifies U.S. tax.

wages_taxed_work_location.name: Wages taxed where the work was physically performed
wages_taxed_work_location.description: Salary is sourced to the country where you actually worked the days (work-day allocation). Default rule in Article XV of the treaty.

us.note: if claiming a foreign tax credit

wages_taxed_work_location.why: Treaty Article XV gives source taxation to the work country; FTC avoids double tax.

short_stay_exemption_us.name: Short-stay treaty exemption for wages (United States)
short_stay_exemption_us.description: A Canadian resident working briefly in the U.S. may be U.S. tax-exempt if the Article XV conditions (incl. ≤183 days and no U.S. employer/PE cost bearing) are met.
short_stay_exemption_us.why: To claim the treaty exemption properly under Article XV.

short_stay_exemption_canada.name: Short-stay treaty exemption for wages (Canada)
short_stay_exemption_canada.description: A U.S. resident working briefly in Canada may be Canadian tax-exempt under Article XV.

canada.note: or Non-resident employer certification so withholding is waived when the treaty applies

short_stay_exemption_canada.why: Prevents payroll withholding when the treaty will exempt the income.

remote_work_canada_for_us.name: Remote work performed in Canada for a U.S. employer
remote_work_canada_for_us.description: Wages are Canadian-source to the extent days were physically in Canada; usually also taxable by the U.S. if you're a U.S. person-use credits to coordinate.

canada.note: employer may need to avoid withholding if you're nonresident of Canada

remote_work_canada_for_us.why: Article XV sources by work location; filings line up withholding and credits.

remote_work_us_for_canada.name: Remote work performed in the United States for a Canadian employer
remote_work_us_for_canada.description: Wages are U.S.-source for days in the U.S.; Canada may tax if you're a Canadian resident-coordinate via credits.
remote_work_us_for_canada.why: Same Article XV sourcing & FTC rationale.

state_convenience_employer.name: State "convenience of the employer" exposure
state_convenience_employer.description: Some U.S. states (e.g., NY, DE) tax wages to the employer's assigned office even when you worked remotely elsewhere, creating unexpected state tax.

state.form: State return(s) where the rule applies
state.note: e.g., NY IT-201/203, plus home-state credit if allowed

state_convenience_employer.why: State rules can ignore treaties; NY's memo explains the "convenience" rule.

state_nonconformity.name: State non-conformity with treaty/FTC
state_nonconformity.description: Many states don't honor U.S. tax treaties or federal FTC rules; you may owe state tax even if federal/treaty relieves it.
state_nonconformity.why: Example: NY generally doesn't allow treaty to exempt state income.

social_security_totalization.name: Social security Totalization & certificate of coverage
social_security_totalization.description: The U.S.–Canada Totalization Agreement generally makes you pay only one social tax system at a time; you document it with a Certificate of Coverage.
social_security_totalization.why: Avoids double FICA/CPP/QPP; the agreement governs coverage and benefits.

canada_reg_102_105.name: Canada Reg. 102/105 waivers & nonresident-employer certification
canada_reg_102_105.description: Canada requires withholding on employment (Reg. 102) and on services by nonresidents (Reg. 105) unless waivers/certifications apply.
canada_reg_102_105.why: Prevents over-withholding when tax is exempt/reduced by treaty or by net-income basis.

us_shareholder_canadian_corp.name: U.S. shareholder of a Canadian corporation
us_shareholder_canadian_corp.description: U.S. person owns certain thresholds in a Canadian corp → U.S. information reporting and potential GILTI/Subpart F inclusions.

us.note: + schedules with your 1040; GILTI computations as applicable

us_shareholder_canadian_corp.why: Sections 6038/6046 require disclosure of specified foreign corporations/CFCs.

canadian_resident_us_llc.name: Canadian resident owning a U.S. LLC (classification mismatch)
canadian_resident_us_llc.description: Canada generally treats a U.S. LLC as a corporation, not a flow-through, which can cause timing/FTC mismatches.

canada.note: as applicable; consider Competent Authority relief if double tax arises

canadian_resident_us_llc.why: CRA guidance indicates LLCs are typically corporate for Canadian tax; Competent Authority can help relieve double taxation.

s_corp_canadian_owner.name: S-corporation shareholder ineligibility for Canadian owners
s_corp_canadian_owner.description: Nonresident aliens cannot be S-corp shareholders; a Canadian nonresident owner breaks S status.

us.note: corporate filings change if S election fails

s_corp_canadian_owner.why: IRC §1361 explicitly bars nonresident alien shareholders.

canadian_gst_hst.name: Canadian GST/HST registration (place-of-supply)
canadian_gst_hst.description: Non-resident sellers doing business in Canada may need GST/HST registration; tax applies using place-of-supply rules.
canadian_gst_hst.why: CRA rules require registration/collection if you carry on business in Canada or make taxable supplies deemed made in Canada.

us_state_sales_tax.name: U.S. state sales/use tax nexus (for Canadians selling to the U.S.)
us_state_sales_tax.description: Economic nexus (post-Wayfair) can create state sales tax duties even without physical presence.
us_state_sales_tax.why: State law-varies; check thresholds in each state.

canadian_us_rental.name: Canadian resident owning U.S. rental property
canadian_us_rental.description: A Canadian resident landlord has U.S. rental income. They can elect net-income treatment.

us.note: with Schedule E; possible §871(d) election to treat rent as ECI; provide W-8ECI to payers if applicable

canadian_us_rental.why: Nonresidents are taxed in the U.S. on U.S.-source income; election allows deductions vs. 30% gross. (W-8ECI is the ECI documentation.)

us_person_canadian_rental.name: U.S. person/nonresident with Canadian rental (Section 216)
us_person_canadian_rental.description: Nonresidents of Canada earning Canadian rent can file a Section 216 return to be taxed on net income.
us_person_canadian_rental.why: Part XIII withholding is 25% of gross unless NR6 approved; 216 return trues up on net.

sale_us_property_nonresident.name: Sale of U.S. real property (non-resident)
sale_us_property_nonresident.description: FIRPTA withholding (generally 15%) on gross sale price; final U.S. tax determined on 1040-NR.
sale_us_property_nonresident.why: FIRPTA ensures collection from nonresidents; the return calculates the actual tax due/refund.

sale_canadian_property_nonresident.name: Sale of Canadian real property (non-resident / U.S. person)
sale_canadian_property_nonresident.description: Nonresidents selling taxable Canadian property must obtain a clearance certificate; otherwise the buyer must withhold.
sale_canadian_property_nonresident.why: CRA requires withholding/clearance to secure tax on dispositions by nonresidents.

cross_border_principal_residence.name: Cross-border principal residence / U.S. §121 coordination
cross_border_principal_residence.description: U.S. citizens/residents may exclude home-sale gain (up to $250k/$500k) under §121; Canada has a principal residence designation (T2091).

us.note: if reporting; follow Topic 701 guidance for §121

cross_border_principal_residence.why: Ensures each country's home-sale rules are applied and disclosures made.

local_vacancy_speculation.name: Local vacancy/speculation taxes (Canada)
local_vacancy_speculation.description: Provincial/municipal vacancy taxes may apply (e.g., BC Speculation & Vacancy Tax; Vancouver Empty Homes Tax), separate from income tax.

vancouver.form: Vancouver EHT: Annual property status declaration

local_vacancy_speculation.why: Compliance is required even if you owe no income tax; penalties are significant.

underused_housing_tax.name: Underused Housing Tax (UHT)
underused_housing_tax.description: Federal 1% tax that can require filings by certain owners of Canadian residential property (including some Canadian corps/trusts) even when no tax is due.
underused_housing_tax.why: Filing obligations exist for many non-"excluded owners"; failure to file triggers penalties.

us_investment_income_canadian.name: U.S. investment income received by a Canadian resident
us_investment_income_canadian.description: U.S. payers withhold on dividends/interest, generally reduced by treaty when you certify eligibility.
us_investment_income_canadian.why: Treaty Articles X/XI reduce withholding; W-8 proves status/benefits.

canadian_investment_income_us.name: Canadian investment income received by a U.S. person/nonresident
canadian_investment_income_us.description: Canadian payers withhold (default 25%) reduced by treaty when eligibility is certified.

canada.note: payer issues; recipient may give NR301 to claim treaty rate

us.note: report and claim FTC if applicable (Form 1116)

canadian_investment_income_us.why: Documentation applies the treaty rate; your return reconciles and credits tax.

pfic_reporting.name: PFIC reporting for Canadian funds
pfic_reporting.description: Many Canadian mutual funds/ETFs are PFICs to the U.S.; detailed annual reporting and potential punitive tax apply.
pfic_reporting.why: U.S. anti-deferral rules require PFIC disclosure and income calculations.

cross_border_financial_accounts.name: Cross-border financial accounts (reporting)
cross_border_financial_accounts.description: Certain non-U.S. (for U.S. persons) or non-Canadian (for Canadian residents) financial assets trigger information reporting.

canada.note: if specified foreign property ≥ CAD $100,000 cost

cross_border_financial_accounts.why: Separate legal regimes (BSA/FATCA/ITAR) require disclosure; penalties for non-filing are steep.

withholding_documentation.name: Withholding documentation maintenance
withholding_documentation.description: Keep the right W-8/W-9/NR forms on file with payers to ensure correct withholding/reporting.
withholding_documentation.why: Payers rely on these to apply treaty rates, avoid backup withholding, and report correctly.

cross_border_retirement_plans.name: Cross-border retirement plans (RRSP/RRIF/401(k)/IRA)
cross_border_retirement_plans.description: Treaty Article XVIII and Rev. Proc. 2014-55 coordinate deferral/recognition and allow U.S. deferral for RRSP/RRIF without Form 8891.

us.note: per rules; information filings as applicable

canada.note: of U.S. plan income per domestic/treaty rules

cross_border_retirement_plans.why: Treaty aligns timing; Rev. Proc. 2014-55 provides automatic U.S. deferral for RRSP/RRIF.

tfsa_resp_us_person.name: TFSA/RESP held by a U.S. person - U.S. reporting
tfsa_resp_us_person.description: These accounts are not covered by Rev. Proc. 2014-55; many fact patterns treat them as foreign trusts (or specified foreign financial assets) for U.S. reporting.
tfsa_resp_us_person.why: Form instructions require reporting for U.S. owners/beneficiaries of foreign trusts; Rev. Proc. 2020-17 exempts some tax-favored foreign trusts-check eligibility.

cross_border_social_benefits.name: Cross-border social benefits
cross_border_social_benefits.description: Taxation of CPP/OAS/U.S. Social Security is set by Article XVIII and subsequent guidance.

us.note: with appropriate inclusion/exclusions for Canadian pensions/annuities

canada.note: with treaty treatment for U.S. Social Security

cross_border_social_benefits.why: The treaty caps withholding and coordinates which country taxes the benefit.

cross_border_pension_rollovers.name: Cross-border pension rollovers/contributions
cross_border_pension_rollovers.description: Some cross-border pension contributions receive treaty relief (deductions/deferrals) if conditions are met.

canada.note: to request treaty relief on contributions

cross_border_pension_rollovers.why: Treaty seeks symmetry so workers aren't penalized when working temporarily in the other country.

equity_cross_border_workdays.name: Equity comp with cross-border workdays
equity_cross_border_workdays.description: RSUs/RSAs/options are allocated by where you performed services during the vest/gain period; Article XV sourcing drives tax and FTC.
equity_cross_border_workdays.why: Aligns equity income to work-day sourcing under the treaty.

option_espp_iso_amt.name: Option/ESPP/ISO AMT review
option_espp_iso_amt.description: ISO exercises can trigger AMT in the U.S.; cross-border allocation still applies.

us.note: as applicable; 1040 and FTC mechanics for cross-border

option_espp_iso_amt.why: AMT adds a second U.S. calculation-plan for credits in Canada/U.S.

us_estate_tax_nonresident.name: U.S. estate tax exposure for nonresident alien
us_estate_tax_nonresident.description: Non-U.S. citizen/nonresident owning U.S.-situated assets can face U.S. estate tax; treaty may provide relief.

us.note: estate of nonresident not a citizen

us_estate_tax_nonresident.why: U.S. imposes estate/GST tax on U.S. situs property owned by nonresidents at death.

us_gift_tax_return.name: U.S. gift tax return requirement
us_gift_tax_return.description: Certain gifts by U.S. persons (and some U.S.-situs gifts by nonresidents) require a gift tax return even if no tax is due.
us_gift_tax_return.why: Tracks use of the lifetime exemption and GST allocations.

cross_border_trusts.name: Cross-border trusts
cross_border_trusts.description: U.S. persons involved with foreign trusts (e.g., some Canadian structures) have annual reporting.
cross_border_trusts.why: U.S. anti-avoidance disclosure rules. (See also Rev. Proc. 2020-17 exceptions.)

fbar_reporting.name: FBAR – FinCEN 114
fbar_reporting.description: U.S. persons must report non-U.S. accounts if the aggregate exceeded $10,000 at any time in the year.
fbar_reporting.why: Bank Secrecy Act reporting-separate from your tax return.

fatca_form_8938.name: FATCA – Form 8938
fatca_form_8938.description: U.S. persons must report specified foreign financial assets when thresholds are met.
fatca_form_8938.why: FATCA disclosure-different thresholds from FBAR, and different penalties.

canada_t1135.name: Canada Form T1135
canada_t1135.description: Canadian residents with specified foreign property ≥ CAD $100,000 (cost) must file.
canada_t1135.why: Foreign asset reporting with significant penalties if late.

compliance_relief_programs.name: Compliance relief programs
compliance_relief_programs.description: If prior years were missed, both countries have programs (e.g., IRS Streamlined, CRA VDP) to correct filings and mitigate penalties.
compliance_relief_programs.why: Formal pathways to come into compliance.
